content.description:
This climbs a striking orange face on the backside of the boulder. Find a pretty good hold at the apex of the orange shield, paste your feet as high as you dare, and mantle. Like the rest of the "Pumping Granite" classics, this one will stay with you a while.

I'm sure this was established from a standing start but the sit start adds a couple cool moves. It's about v3 from a sit.
content.location: Behind Where Boneheads Dare are 2 more enormous boulders. This is on the last one facing away from the campground.

content.description:
This problem lies on the right hand side of the slabby boulder, just to the left of the small boulder.  The ground at the start slopes downwards toward "Where Boneheads Dare". Start at the thin left-arching/horizontal seam/crack and mantel up on its crimpy rail past the bare face above to two bomber huecos.  Scramble to the top, and descend to the right via easy terrain.

V1 rating is taken from the "5 Star Bouldering in Southern California" guide by Bertini, Close and Newell, and feels fair.
content.location: This problem is about 30-40 yards away from the camp loop, on the third or fourth large boulder. Walk uphill toward Flowerpot boulder from campsites 20/21, keeping "Where Boneheads Dare" on your left.  Look left to the intersection of two large boulders (chimney problem in the middle, and a highball V3 problem on orange rock on the lefthand boulder).  This problem is to the right of the chimney problem on the far right of the slab face.
